I.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
 
1.  The COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure Support (CARES) Program will support 
government efforts in mitigating the severe economic and social impact of COVID-19. The 
program comprises (i) loans of $500 million to help the Government of Bangladesh to expand and 
strengthen its social safety net for the vulnerable groups including women, as well as to support 
major export industries in order to protect jobs, and (ii) a transaction technical assistance (TRTA) 
of $1 million to facilitate the implementation of the program and to improve the overall efficiency 
of the social safety net program.  
 
2.  The objective of the program is to support the government in mitigating the significant 
adverse social and economic impacts caused by the COVID-19 pandemic and is aligned with 
Bangladesh’s Seventh Five Year Plan FY2016–FY2020 goal on inequality and unemployment 
reduced1. Bangladesh’s economy is likely to be severely affected by the slowdown and disruption 
of economic activities, as well as by the spillover effects of the recession in many of its major 
trade partners. The government’s planned fiscal stimulus program includes an enhanced social 
assistance to the vulnerable groups of the population and job protection programs to support 
small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and key export industries. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  Beyond the impact of the health crisis, the pandemic will have a severe negative impact 
on the economy. Based on IMF projections, the country’s economy growth will drop to 3.8%, the 
lowest growth since 2002. There are three main channels through which the pandemic will affect 
the economy: (i) slowdown in domestic economy; (ii) sharp decline in exports; and (iii) reduction 
in remittances. To mitigate the negative impact on its economy and protect the affected people, 
the government announced a fiscal stimulus program and requested ADB to provide a COVID-19 
support and response program of $500 million to complement its implementation. 
 
4.  The program will support government efforts in mitigating the severe social and economic 
impact of COVID-19. The pandemic is expected to have a lasting negative impact on the 
vulnerable groups including women. As of FY2019, 20.5% of the population live below the poverty 
line of which 10.5% suffer from extreme poverty.2 Almost half of the population live barely above 
the poverty line—85% of the total workforce (for women, 92%) operate in the informal economy, 
living hand to mouth.3 The livelihood of these small traders, day laborers, and other informal 
workers is threatened by the nationwide lockdown and the ensuing economic downturn. Most 
women in the labor force are concentrated in the informal economy earning wages that barely 
manage to lift them above the poverty line. Even under normal circumstances, the lack of secure 
employment, low wages, and discriminatory practices place women in an especially vulnerable 
position. The impact of COVID-19 further exacerbates this situation. ADB estimates the pandemic 
to put an additional 7.7% of the population (close to 13 million people) under the national poverty 
line.  With  social  distancing  measures  being  put  in  place  and  lockdown  measures  being 
implemented, there has been a rise in domestic violence as women are forced to stay at home 
with their abusive partners. The program complements government budget to provide targeted

and timely support to the most vulnerable groups of the population through cash and in-kind 
payments as well as expanded public work programs. This support will be delivered through 
existing channels for implementation efficiency, while capacity support will be provided through 
the attached TRTA.  
 
5.  The social safety net programs in the country have a total budget of Tk 642 billion in 
FY2019, which is equivalent to 2.5% of GDP. These programs comprise cash allowance, public 
works, humanitarian relief, and education incentives for poor and vulnerable households. Cash 
transfer programs cover old age allowance, vulnerable women, and persons with disabilities. 
Social security for about 4.6 million women is ensured through programs for widows, women 
oppressed by husbands, and distressed women and through elderly and disabled allowances, in 
which women’s quota is set at 50% minimum. However, with only 6.4 million covered under three 
programs and payment ranging from $2.0 to $8.5 a month, these programs are inadequate in 
terms of coverage and level of support even during normal times. Public work programs such as 
the 100-day employment generation program pays up to $2.5 in daily wages for the 0.9 million 
poor to perform public work. Despite the broad array of programs available, there is significant 
room for improvement in terms of efficiency of service delivery and governance to improve 
beneficiary experience. Nevertheless, these programs provide the best suited channels to deliver 
services in fighting the pandemic and to upgrade their capacity, will be critical in managing the 
current crisis as well as to prepare for future calamities. 
  
6.  The social safety net programs need to be further expanded both in terms of budget and 
number  of  beneficiaries  because  of  the  recent  impact  of  COVID-19  in  the  country.  The 
government will offer cash aid to poor families that have been hit hard by the ongoing shutdown 
amid coronavirus scare. The government has planned one-off transfer Tk 2,000 in cash to each 
of 2 million families, whose breadwinners have lost their jobs because of the lockdown, as part of 
its efforts to keep the most vulnerable segment of the society at home. The government has 
allocated $50 million for this group of people4. Government to Person (G2P) mobile banking 
channels will be used to transfer this payment. With the government rolling out various pro-poor 
expenditures through existing social safety net programs to combat the pandemic, more capacity 
support development and policy advisory on pandemic response for efficient coordination among 
the government agencies and structural reforms will be needed. It will also require support for 
stronger monitoring and evaluation (M&E) framework to ensure transparency and efficiency. 
  
7.  In the FY 2019-2020, the government has targeted to include 11.3 million poor people 
under 17 social protection and several other social safety net programs5. The government has 
planned to gradually bring all cash transfers under the G2P system. Under this system, payments 
are processed from the government exchequer to the beneficiary’s bank or mobile bank account.  
   
8.  The TRTA has the following outputs: (i) support the program implementation by providing 
capacity support and development; (ii) provide direct support for the delivery of services through 
the existing social safety net; (iii) introduce new tools and solutions to improve poverty and gender 
targeting and service delivery, including digital financial services and banking channels; (iv) 
develop a gender-responsive plan to improve the social safety net in the country; and (v) improve 
the monitoring and evaluation capacity and data collection. The TRTA will provide technical

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $1 million financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The respective implementing agencies (IAs) will provide 
counterpart support in the form of office space, counterpart staff, logistical support and other in-
kind contributions. These IAs will give access to the consultants and data entry operators to their 
respective MIS and software relevant to social safety net beneficiary database. The TA will be 
supervised  and  administered  by  ADB  Technical  Assistance  Supervising  Unit  (TASU).  TA 
disbursement  will  follow  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). The TA will be implemented over two years. The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB’s South Asia Department will select, supervise, and 
evaluate the consultants in consultation with the Finance Division of the Ministry of Finance 
(MOF). ADB will recruit a consulting firm with international and national consultants using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10 because of the highly 
specialized expertise needed. An output-based (lumpsum) contract will be used for the firm 
contract. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
Procurement of goods and non-consultancy services, if any, will be procured by following the ADB 
Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the Procurement Regulations for 
ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). The implementation arrangements are 
summarized in Table 2.
